content:
Yes, several new initiatives and programs were launched in honor of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday celebration. Here are some examples:

1. The Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother Scholarship: The Royal Agricultural University in England established this scholarship to support postgraduate students in agricultural and rural management courses.

2. The Queen Mother's Clothing Guild: This charity, which was founded by the Queen Mother in 1926, launched a fundraising campaign to mark her centenary. The campaign aimed to raise £1 million to provide clothes and other essential items to elderly people in need. 

3. The Queen Mother's Legacy Fund: The fund was launched by The Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Philip, in memory of his late mother-in-law. It supports projects that benefit young people, the elderly, and other vulnerable groups in society.

4. The Queen Mother Centenary Walk: In 2000, the Royal Parks Foundation created a new walking route in London to celebrate the Queen Mother's 100th birthday. The 2.5-mile route takes visitors through several of the city's famous parks and gardens, including St James's Park, Green Park, Hyde Park, and Kensington Gardens.

5. The Queen Mother's Birthday Parade: To mark her 100th birthday, a special parade was held in London, featuring over 1,000 soldiers, cavalry, and bands from the British Army, Navy, and Air Force. The Queen Mother, who was then the oldest member of the royal family, watched the parade from the balcony of Buckingham Palace, alongside other members of the royal family.
